required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Incidence Of Hemidiaphragmatic Paralysis After Usg Guided Low Dose Interscalene Brachial Plexus Block
clinical_study.official_title: Incidence Of Hemidiaphragmatic Paralysis With Patient Controlled Infusion Of Low Volume Of Ropivacaine After Usg Guided Low Dose Interscalene Brachial Plexus Block

lead_sponsor.agency: Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research

clinical_study.source: Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research

brief_summary.textblock: to put a catheter in interscalene brachial plexus USG guided and give a bolus of drug followed by 24 hours continous infusion of drug

detailed_description.textblock: to put a catheter in interscalene brachial plexus USG guided and give a bolus of drug followed by 24 hours continous infusion of drug. To see hemidiaphragmatic paralysis by seeing diaphragmatic excursion on M mode Usg subcostal approach, to see post operative pain, patient satisfaction score, complications if any

primary_outcome.description: incidence of hemidiaphragmatic paralysis by M mode USG to be seen

arm_group.description: will be given block and continuous infusion with bolus 10ml of 0.5% ropivacaine followed by infusion @ 2ml/hr of 0.2% ropivacaine
IV analgesia only with diclofenac and paracetamol

intervention.intervention_name: Interscalene Block with Ropivacaine Hcl 0.2% Inj Vil 10Ml
intervention.description: bolus 10ml of 0.5% ropivacaine followed by infusion @ 2ml/hr of 0.2% ropivacaine
iv diclofenac 75 mg TDS iv paracetamol 1gm TDS

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients aged 18-80 years and belonging to ASA grade I, II, III, undergoing either, shoulder surgery, (rotator cuff repair, acromioplasty, hemiarthroplasty, and total shoulder replacement) or surgery for proximal humerus fracture will be recruited for the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- a) Patient refusal for interscalene block b) Severe respiratory disease (FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 80% of predicted) c) Allergy to amide local anaesthetic drugs d) Chronic opioid therapy e) Patients who cannot understand how to operate PCA and VAS

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research
responsible_party.investigator_title: Junior resident, Department of Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, MD
